{{Short description|German electronic music group}} {{More citations needed|date=March 2020}} {{Infobox musical artist | name = Blutengel | image = Blutengel-blackfieldfestival-2013.jpg | caption = Blutengel performing on the Blackfield Festival 2013 | image_size = | alias = | origin = [[Berlin]], [[Germany]] | instrument = | genre = {{Flatlist| * [[Darkwave]] * [[futurepop]] * [[synthpop]] }} | occupation = | years_active = 1998–present | label = [[Out of Line Music]] | associated_acts = {{Plainlist| * [[Seelenkrank]] * [[Tristesse de la Lune]] * [[Terminal Choice]] * [[Miss Construction]] * Tumor * Cinderella Effect * Say Y * Waldgeist * Stendal Blast * [[Staubkind]] * [[Sara Noxx]] * [[Chrome (band)|Chrome]] * [[Lord of the Lost]] }} | website = | current_members = [[:de:Chris Pohl|Chris Pohl]]
[[Ulrike Goldmann]] | past_members = {{Plainlist| * [[Nina Bendigkeit]] * [[Kati Roloff]] * [[Gini Martin]] * [[Eva Pölzing]] * Sonja Semmler * [[:de:Constance Rudert|Constance Rudert]] * Steffi Weingarten * Anja Milow }} }} '''Blutengel''' ({{lang-de|Blood Angel}}) (stylized as '''BlutEngel''') is a German [[electronic music]] group formed by singer [[:de:Chris Pohl|Chris Pohl]] (also of the groups [[Terminal Choice]], Tumor, and [[Miss Construction]] and the owner of the Fear Section label) after he had to leave [[Seelenkrank]] due to contractual and legal problems. The lyrics are written primarily in German and English and are presented with male and female vocals. The themes of the songs usually centre around themes common in [[Gothic fiction]] such as love, [[vampirism]], sexual fetishism, death, and [[immortality]]. The band calls their musical style ''dark pop''.{{cite web|url=http://blutengel.de/2016/06/ |title=Blutengel | 2016 Juni |website=Blutengel.de |date=2016-07-30 |accessdate=2020-03-23}} == History == ===Formation and early years (1998–2001)=== Blutengel was formed in 1998 after Chris Pohl had decided to give up the preceding project, [[Seelenkrank]] (which had released two albums), due to contractual problems. Just as its predecessor, Blutengel uses melodious electronic tunes in combination with both male and female voices. The lyrics are primarily in German or English and mixed between male and female vocals paired with electronic sounds and with songs often focusing on all aspects of love, from the tragedy of hopeless romance of vampires (all the way to the more animal aspects of desire) and aspects of death and the afterlife. The first album ''[[Child of Glass (Blutengel album)|Child of Glass]]'' was released in early 1999 with [[Kati Roloff]] and [[Nina Bendigkeit]] as the original female vocalists. In 2001, the second album ''[[Seelenschmerz]]'' was released. Nina left to concentrate on photography and eventually form the band Formalin. [[Gini Martin]] joined the band as the second female voice alongside Kati. The first Blutengel gig ever took place at the [[Wave-Gotik-Treffen]] on June 1, 2001, in Leipzig, in front of 10,000 fans.{{Citation needed|date=April 2018}} At the end of 2001, the single ''Black Roses'' was released with [[:de:Constance Rudert|Constance Rudert]] as a session singer. The band performed at the Dark Storm Festival where Constance appeared on stage with Kati and Gini. This was the last time the band would play with its original line-up. Kati and Gini left the band days later for personal reasons and founded their own project together, [[Tristesse de la Lune]]. Constance, who had originally only been recruited for the single "Black Roses", became a full time member of Blutengel. [[Eva Pölzing]] joined soon after as a second vocalist. ===Rise in popularity (2002–2008)=== ''[[Angel Dust (Blutengel album)|Angel Dust]]'' was released in 2002, placing 58th on the German Charts.{{cite web|url=https://www.offiziellecharts.de/album-details-25810|title=Offizielle Deutsche Charts: Blutengel - Angel Dust |author=|website=Offiziellecharts.de|access-date=11 April 2018}} The ''Angel Dust'' promotional photo-shoot and booklet was made by Nina Bendigkeit. In 2004 their fourth album, ''[[Demon Kiss]]'', was released, featuring the single "Forever". A DVD release ''[[Live Lines (Blutengel)|Live Lines]]'' and the album-length EP ''[[The Oxidising Angel]]'' appeared in 2005, the latter of which contained new material as well as a cover of "[[Cry Little Sister]]" from [[The Lost Boys (soundtrack)|''The Lost Boys'' soundtrack]]. In early October Eva Pölzing decided to leave the band due to other projects.{{Citation needed|date=April 2018}} Eva was replaced by [[Ulrike Goldmann]] (ex-[[Say-Y]]). For the following two years, the band released a couple of singles with a slightly more "pop-driven" sound until their fifth album, ''[[Labyrinth (Blutengel album)|Labyrinth]]'' was released in September 2007. It reached 36th in the German charts,{{cite web|url=https://www.offiziellecharts.de/album-details-67662|title=Offizielle Deutsche Charts: Blutengel - Labyrinth |author=|website=Offiziellecharts.de|access-date=11 April 2018}} and featured the single "Lucifer", and the live favourite "Engelsblut". ===Extended albums (2009–2012)=== In 2009 Blutengel released the album ''[[Schwarzes Eis]]'', which featured the single "Dancing in the Light" and accompanying music video to promote the album. An extended edition of this album contained three full CDs, each with its own subtitle (''Schwarzes Eis'', the instrumental ''Behind the Mirror'' and ''Redemption''). The EP ''[[Soultaker (Blutengel EP)|Soultaker]]'' was released later that year. In 2010, they performed at the Amphi Festival featuring Anja Milow, Maria Rehfeld and Jenny Haufe who had been hired in 2009 as a dancers for the Schwarzes Eis Tour. Days later, it was announced on the official website that Constance had been replaced by two new singers, Anja Milow and Steffi Weingarten. Both featured on the seventh album ''[[Tränenherz]]'', released in 2011 and placed in the German charts at number 12.{{cite web|url=https://www.offiziellecharts.de/album-details-152096|title=Offizielle Deutsche Charts: Blutengel - Tränenherz |author=|website=Offiziellecharts.de|access-date=11 April 2018}} Two singles "Über den Horizont" & "Reich Mir Die Hand" were released to promote the album, with accompanying music videos the latter featuring Pohl's new girlfriend Viki Scarlet as the "Bloody Girl" in Reich Mir Die Hand who would later become a permanent dancer.{{Citation needed|date=April 2018}} The EP ''[[Nachtbringer]]'' followed that same year. a music video was released for the title track featuring the complete lineup excluding Jenny for this video. Steffi was fired from the band before they began touring and on her official Facebook page, she wrote a statement claiming that she was not allowed to tour due to legal issues with Constance.{{Citation needed|date=April 2018}} Jenny left in 2012, followed by Anja to focus on her job as a model for the clothing label AMF Korsets, continue college studies and work as an independent designer with her label Madone Noire. ===''Monument'' and ''Black Symphonies'' (2012–2014)=== From May 12 to May 20, 2012 Blutengel toured North America for the first time. Playing in [[Mexico City]], [[New York City|New York]], [[San Antonio]], [[San Francisco]], [[Los Angeles]], and in [[Montreal]] for the [[Kinetik Festival]]. After the tour Maria Rehfeld left the band.{{Citation needed|date=April 2018}} The first single from the album ''[[Monument (Blutengel album)|Monument]]'', "Save Our Souls", was released in November 2012 while the second single, "You Walk Away", was released in January 2013. The album ''Monument'' was released in February 2013 and placed #4 & #96 on the German and Switzerland music charts respectively. "''Kinder dieser Stadt''{{-"}} was released on July 19, 2013, as the third single from ''Monument''. Blutengel released an orchestral compilation album, ''[[Black Symphonies (An Orchestral Journey)]]'', on February 28, 2014. A single and music video for "Krieger" were released to promote the album. ===Omen & Nemesis: The Best of & Reworked (2014–2016)=== The first single "Asche Zu Asche", from their upcoming album was released on November 14, 2014. The second single, "Sing", was released on January 23, 2015. ''[[Omen (Blutengel album)|Omen]]'' was released on February 12, 2015. The band then embarked on the first leg of the ''Omen'' tour in April and spanning through to August. Festival appearances include [[Wave-Gotik-Treffen]], [[Mera Luna Festival]], and [[Summer Breeze Open Air]]. A new EP, ''[[In Alle Ewigkeit]]'', was announced via the band's website in early August as well as the tour dates for the second leg of the Omen tour, which began in November and ended in early December. The new EP was released 23 October 2015, and featured a reworking of 'Weg Zu Mir' originally from 'Child of Glass' which served as a preview for the upcoming 'Best of' album.{{cite web |url=http://www.outoflineshop.de/back-catalogue/b/blutengel/in-alle-ewigkeit.html |title=Out of Line Shop in Alle Ewigkeit Out of Line Shop |access-date=2015-10-15 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151031131406/http://www.outoflineshop.de/back-catalogue/b/blutengel/in-alle-ewigkeit.html |archive-date=2015-10-31 |url-status=dead }} Chris Pohl recorded guest vocals on Italian industrial group Helalyn Flowers' "Beware of Light" single which was released by Belgian label Alfa Matrix Records in October 2015.{{cite web|url=https://alfamatrix.bandcamp.com/album/beware-of-light-feat-chris-pohl-ep|title=Beware Of Light (feat. Chris Pohl) EP, by HELALYN FLOWERS|website=Alfa Matrix|access-date=2020-01-04}} On 26 February 2016, their 'best of' album ''[[Nemesis: The Best of & Reworked]]'' was released with re-recorded versions of BlutEngel classics. To support this release, they will be playing 'Nemesis - Open Air Festival' in July.{{cite web |url=http://www.outofline.de/content/newsletter/newsletter101215.htm# |title=Blutengel: Nemesis - the Open Air 2016 |access-date=2015-12-10 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151211125849/http://www.outofline.de/content/newsletter/newsletter101215.htm# |archive-date=2015-12-11 |url-status=dead }} Due to legal issues, ''Omen'' was re-released under the title ''Save Us''.{{cite web|url=http://www.side-line.com/blutengel-forced-to-rename-open-album-to-save-us-due-to-legal-dispute/|title=Blutengel forced to rename 'Omen' album to 'Save Us' due to legal dispute |website=Side-line.com|date=26 June 2016 |access-date=17 October 2017}} ===Leitbild & Un:Gott (2016–present)=== In early 2016, BlutEngel entered the studio to record a new album, set for a release in February 2017. "Complete", the first single from the upcoming 10th album, ''[[Leitbild (Blutengel album)|Leitbild]]'', was released on December 2, 2016. it featured two B-sides and a remix by British darkwave act [[Massive Ego]]. The second single "Lebe Deinen Traum" was released as a digital single on February 3, 2017. ''[[Leitbild (Blutengel album)|Leitbild]]'' was released on 17 February. The album would be the band's third straight album to chart in the top 5 of the [[Media Control Charts]] at number 4. The album would also chart [[Swiss Hitparade|Swiss Music Charts]] at #49. BlutEngel went on Tour starting in April and ended in May to promote ''Leitbild'', with Massive Ego as their support. On 12 May, they performed an acoustic set which was recorded for release on DVD as, [[A Special Night Out: Live & Acoustic in Berlin]]. After the ''Leitbild'' tour ended, Chris teased that he began work on a new Mini Album or EP to be released towards the end of the year. The new Mini Album was later confirmed and entitled ''Black''. The 2nd leg of the ''Leitbild'' tour was also announced for October through December, 2017. [[Live im Wasserschloss Klaffenbach]] will be released April 2018, with footage from their 'Nemesis - Open Air Festival' from July 2016. In May, 2018 BlutEngel were back in the studio working on their next album, Un:Gott, which was released 15 February 2019 and was promoted with a tour, that began in February. The tour was once again supported by [[Massive Ego]]. A new Mini Album "Damokles" was released on November 1, 2019. During the [[COVID-19 pandemic]] three singles were released. The first ''Wir Sind Unsterblich'' on 27 March. The second, ''Obscured'', a collaboration with [[Hocico]] on 3 April. The third, ''Nothing But A Void'', a collaboration with Massive Ego will be released Friday 13 November. == Line-up == === Current members === * [[:de:Chris Pohl|Chris Pohl]] – vocals, lyrics, programming (1998–present) * [[Ulrike Goldmann]] – vocals and lyrics (2005–present) === Current dancers === * Viki Scarlet – Main Visual Concept (2011–present) === Former members === * 1998–2000: [[Nina Bendigkeit]] (now in Formalin;[http://www.myspace.com/formalin Formalin] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100311002204/http://www.myspace.com/formalin |date=March 11, 2010 }} also female voices on [[Seelenkrank]] and [[Terminal Choice]] albums) – Vocals and lyrics * 1998–2002: [[Kati Roloff]] (was in [[Tristesse de la Lune]] with [[Gini Martin|Gini]] but left in late 2006) – Vocals * 2000–2002: [[Gini Martin]] (now in [[Tristesse de la Lune]]) – Vocals and Lyrics * 2002–2005: [[Eva Pölzing]] (now in F.O.D[http://www.fod-band.de F.O.D] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080411163416/http://www.fod-band.de/ |date=April 11, 2008 }}) – Vocals * 2002–2010: [[:de:Constance Rudert|Constance Rudert]] (now in Cinderella Effect)– session singer then Vocals and Visual Concept{{Cite web |url=http://www.zillo.de/template.cgi?page=news_detail&id=45 |title=Zillo Musikmagazin - Constance Rudert und Blutengel gehen getrennte Wege |access-date=2016-06-21 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160808174619/http://www.zillo.de/template.cgi?page=news_detail&id=45 |archive-date=2016-08-08 |url-status=dead }} * 2010–2011: Steffi Weingarten – Vocals * 2009–2012: Anja Milow – Vocals and Visual Concept === Former dancers === * 2001–2009: Sonja Semmler (now in Masters of Comedy[http://www.masters-of-comedy.com/ Masters of Comedy] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120622174133/http://www.masters-of-comedy.com/ |date=June 22, 2012 }}) – Live performance, visual concept (their first official dancer/performance artist to be part of the band) * 2009-2012: Jenny Haufe- Visual Concept * 2009-2012: Maria Rehfeld- Visual Concept == Discography == {{main|Blutengel discography}} === Studio albums === * 1999: ''[[Child of Glass (album)|Child of Glass]]'' * 2001: ''[[Seelenschmerz]]'' * 2002: ''[[Angel Dust (Blutengel album)|Angel Dust]]'' * 2004: ''[[Demon Kiss]]'' * 2007: ''[[Labyrinth (Blutengel album)|Labyrinth]]'' * 2009: ''[[Schwarzes Eis]]'' * 2011: ''[[Tränenherz]]'' * 2013: ''[[Monument (Blutengel album)|Monument]]'' * 2015: ''[[Omen (Blutengel album)|Omen/Save Us]]'' * 2017: ''[[Leitbild (Blutengel album)|Leitbild]]'' * 2019: ''Un:Gött'' * 2021: ''Erlösung -
